Name: Geography (Geographica)
Metaphysical Tags: Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Multiplicities (Plural Ontologies), War (Dialectical Materialism)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Foundational Abstract Sciences: Geometry, Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Warfare, Human Sciences: Economics, Human Sciences: Taxonomic Classification, Human Sciences: Linguistics, Human Sciences: Education, Liberal Arts: History, Liberal Arts: Anthropology
Short Description: A monumental 17-book encyclopedic work that blends geography, history, ethnography, mythology, and political commentary. The text presents a detailed description of the known world from the Atlantic Ocean to India, structured according to regions and peoples. Strabo integrates earlier sources (such as Homer, Eratosthenes, Herodotus, and Polybius) with his own observations, producing a sweeping account that reflects both scientific curiosity and imperial ideology.

Name: On the Names of the Parts of the Human Body
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Medicine, Natural & Physical Sciences: Biology, Natural & Physical Sciences: Neuroscience/Systems Biology, Human Sciences: Taxonomic Classification, Human Sciences: Education
Short Description: A concise anatomical treatise that catalogs the Greek names of various human body parts, organized from head to toe. Designed as a reference for medical students and practitioners, the text provides brief descriptions of each organ’s structure, location, and function. It reflects the rational, empirical spirit of Greco-Roman medicine and contributes to the standardization of anatomical terminology.
Name.1: On the Names of the Parts of the Human Body
Author: Rufus of Ephesus
Literary Forms Tags: Glossary / Taxonomy, Manual / Instruction, Doctrine / Treatise

Name: On the Interrogation of the Patient
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Monism
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Medicine, Natural & Physical Sciences: Neuroscience/Systems Biology, Human Sciences: Psychology, Human Sciences: Education, Human Sciences: Taxonomic Classification
Short Description: A concise treatise that outlines how physicians should question patients to accurately diagnose illness. Emphasizing the importance of careful listening, observation, and logical inference, Rufus provides a structured method for gathering information—beginning with general lifestyle questions and moving toward specific symptoms. The text reflects the Greco-Roman medical ideal of rational, ethical care, presenting dialogue as the foundation of effective healing.

Name: On Melancholy
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Monism
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Medicine, Natural & Physical Sciences: Neuroscience/Systems Biology, Human Sciences: Psychology, Human Sciences: Taxonomic Classification, Liberal Arts: Philosophy
Short Description: An early medical treatise that investigates melancholia as a distinct mental disorder caused by an excess of black bile. Combining humoral theory with clinical observation, Rufus describes its symptoms—such as irrational fear, sadness, withdrawal, and delusion—and distinguishes it from similar conditions like mania and phrenitis. The text offers guidance for diagnosis and treatment, marking one of the first systematic attempts to understand mental illness as both a bodily and psychological phenomenon within a rational, empirical framework.

Name: On the Pulse
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Monism
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Medicine, Natural & Physical Sciences: Neuroscience/Systems Biology, Human Sciences: Psychology, Human Sciences: Taxonomic Classification, Human Sciences: Education
Short Description: A concise treatise that teaches physicians how to diagnose illness by examining the pulse. It explains the pulse’s origin in the heart, outlines different types of pulses (e.g., fast, slow, strong, weak), and links pulse variations to specific diseases, emotional states, and physical conditions. Emphasizing tactile skill, observation, and logical interpretation, the text serves as a practical guide for medical students and professionals within the Greco-Roman empirical tradition.
Neumann Stages Tags: Initiation, Mythic Ordering of Reality, Return to the Community

Name: Diogenes of Oenoanda inscription
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Genesis (Process Realism), Multiplicities (plural Ontologies), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Inversion (Subversive Ontology)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Physics, Natural & Physical Sciences: Biology, Natural & Physical Sciences: Astronomy, Human Sciences: Psychology, Human Sciences: Education, Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Liberal Arts: Philosophy, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: A massive public stone inscription commissioned by Diogenes, an affluent Epicurean philosopher from the city of Oenoanda in Lycia (modern-day Turkey). Stretching over 80 meters, it serves as an extensive summary of Epicurean philosophy, including writings on ethics, physics, epistemology, and theology. Diogenes believed that sharing Epicurus’ teachings would liberate others from fear, especially fear of death and the gods. He inscribed the text on a stoa wall in a public square to ensure access for all literate citizens and travelers. It is one of the most ambitious public philosophical inscriptions from antiquity and a rare example of Epicurean doctrine etched into civic space.

Name: Orations
Metaphysical Tags: Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Monism, Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Phenomena (Phenomenology)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Public Relations, Human Sciences: Education, Liberal Arts: Philosophy, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: A collection of over 50 speeches in the Second Sophistic style. They include panegyrics to Rome and the emperors (Roman Oration), praise of Greek cities like Athens and Smyrna, philosophical reflections on rhetoric and truth, and polemical defenses of oratory. The speeches function both as literary showpieces of Greek rhetorical artistry and as imperial panegyrics, legitimizing Rome’s rule as divinely ordained and universally beneficial. Aristides uses the orations to bridge Greek cultural pride with Roman political supremacy, presenting Rome as the guarantor of peace and justice while celebrating Greek intellectual heritage.

Name: Sacred Tales
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Medicine, Human Sciences: Psychology, Liberal Arts: Theology, Liberal Arts: Philosophy, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: A six-book autobiographical account of his prolonged illnesses and the miraculous cures he attributed to the god Asclepius. The text records dreams, visions, ritual prescriptions, and Aristides’ unwavering devotion, effectively serving both as a diary and a votive offering. More than a personal narrative, it testifies to the enduring efficacy of divine healing and the authority of traditional cult practices. By elevating Asclepius above rational medicine, Aristides reaffirmed the legitimacy of the Greco-Roman sacred order. In doing so, the Sacred Tales upheld the cultural and religious status quo, presenting pagan sacred knowledge as still vital and authoritative within the Roman imperial context.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Wise Old Man, Initiator, Hero, Persona

Name: Orphic Hymns
Metaphysical Tags: Apophasis, Genesis (Process Realism), Multiplicities (Plural Ontologies), Monism, Phenomena (Phenomenology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Inversion (Subversive Ontology)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Liberal Arts: Philosophy, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: A collection of 87 devotional poems in dactylic hexameter, preserved in a standardized form during the Hellenistic and early Roman periods, likely in Asia Minor. These redactions revise and compile older Orphic hymns rooted in archaic Greek mystery traditions, blending local cult practices with a unified Orphic cosmology. Each hymn invokes a specific deity or cosmic principle, praising their attributes and powers before requesting blessings, protection, or favor. Rich in mythic imagery and ritual language, the collection served both as liturgy for initiates and as a poetic expression of Orphic theology, emphasizing purification, divine justice, the soul’s immortality, and the cycles of death and rebirth.

Name: Oneirocritica (Interpretation of Dreams)
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Multiplicities (plural Ontologies), Genesis (Process Realism), Apophasis
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Psychology, Human Sciences: Taxonomic Classification, Liberal Arts: Theology
Short Description: A five-book manual on dream interpretation — the most extensive surviving work of its kind from antiquity. It blends general rules with thousands of case studies that Artemidorus collected during his travels through Asia Minor, Greece, and Italy. The text classifies dreams into systematic categories (body parts, animals, professions, rituals, public life) and explains how their meanings change depending on the dreamer’s social status, gender, or circumstances. Artemidorus presents dream interpretation as a professional science, defending its legitimacy against skeptics and emphasizing empirical observation and tested cases.

Name: On Epideictic Speeches
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Education, Human Sciences: Public Relations, Liberal Arts: Literature, Liberal Arts: Art/Aesthetics, Liberal Arts: Philosophy
Short Description: A late antique rhetorical manual that gives detailed instructions for composing and delivering ceremonial orations. It covers the structure, themes, and stylistic techniques appropriate for various types of public praise speeches—such as imperial encomia, civic panegyrics, wedding orations, and funeral speeches. Menander outlines how to praise cities (their geography, history, culture), rulers (ancestry, virtues, deeds), and individuals, often blending historical exempla with idealized moral qualities. The work reflects the Greek rhetorical tradition adapted to the needs of the Roman imperial elite, serving as a practical guide for professional orators and students of rhetoric in formal, honorific contexts.

Name: Easily Procured Remedies (Euporista)
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Genesis (Process Realism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Medicine, Natural & Physical Sciences: Biology, Natural & Physical Sciences: Chemistry, Human Sciences: Education, Liberal Arts: History
Short Description: A concise medical handbook, designed to provide practical, accessible treatments for common ailments. It compiles a range of remedies that rely on readily available ingredients, making it useful for situations where specialized medical resources were limited. The work draws heavily from earlier Greek medical authorities, especially Galen, distilling their more complex prescriptions into simplified, actionable instructions. Its focus is pragmatic rather than theoretical, prioritizing effectiveness and ease of preparation over elaborate explanation. As such, it served as a functional reference for physicians, travelers, and literate laypeople seeking efficient solutions to everyday health issues.

Name: Medical Collections
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Genesis (Process Realism), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Cosmological Rationalism), Monism
Arts and Sciences Tags: Natural & Physical Sciences: Medicine, Natural & Physical Sciences: Biology, Natural & Physical Sciences: Neuroscience/Systems Biology, Human Sciences: Education, Liberal Arts: Philosophy, Liberal Arts: Anthropology
Short Description: A massive compendium of Greek medical knowledge, commissioned by Emperor Julian. Drawing heavily from Galen, Hippocrates, and other classical authorities, it aimed to preserve the core principles and techniques of ancient medicine. The work originally comprised 70 volumes, covering anatomy, physiology, pathology, dietetics, pharmacology, and surgical practice. It was designed as both a scholarly archive and a practical manual for physicians in diagnosis and treatment. Though much of it is lost, the surviving parts remain one of the most comprehensive snapshots of late Greco-Roman medical science.

Name: Orations
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Multiplicities (Plural Ontologies), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Education, Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human sciences: Public Relations, Liberal Arts: History, Liberal Arts: Philosophy
Short Description: A collection of speeches and rhetorical displays ranging from autobiographical pieces (Or. 1, Autobiography), to panegyrics for emperors and governors, to defenses of traditional religion and education (Or. 30, For the Temples). Beyond their literary artistry, they carry a clear cultural agenda: Libanius presents himself as a custodian of Hellenic paideia and a defender of the civic role of rhetoric, philosophy, and pagan cults. In an age when Christianity was rapidly rising and gaining imperial patronage, his orations functioned as a cultural and religious apologetic—an effort to preserve and legitimize the Hellenic way of life, its ancestral gods, and its educational traditions.

Name: Letters
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomena (Phenomenology), Multiplicities (Plural Ontologies), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Monism, Inversion (Subversive Ontology)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Education, Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human sciences: Public Relations, Liberal Arts: History, Liberal Arts: Philosophy
Short Description: One of the most vast and unique epistolary corpora of antiquity, with over 1,500 surviving pieces. Written in refined Atticizing Greek, they range from personal reflections on illness and friendship to appeals on behalf of students, civic petitions, defenses of Hellenic culture, and even letters addressed directly to emperors. Beyond their literary artistry, they function as a window into the social, cultural, and political processes of the late united Roman Empire, revealing how an elite pagan intellectual navigated shifting power structures and the rise of Christianity. The letters preserve not only Libanius’ voice but also the networks of education, patronage, and civic identity that bound Antioch to the wider imperial world.

Name: Orations
Arts and Sciences Tags: Liberal Arts: Theology, Liberal Arts: Philosophy, Liberal Arts: History, Human Sciences: Political Science/Law, Human Sciences: Education
Short Description: A collection of forty-five rhetorical-theological discourses which includes the celebrated Theological Orations, funeral speeches, festal sermons, and personal defenses of his ministry. Their core aim was to defend Nicene orthodoxy against Arian and Eunomian opponents, articulate the doctrine of the Trinity, and assert the authority of bishops in a Christianizing empire. At once theological, rhetorical, and political, they blend classical Greco-Roman oratory with Christian dogma, becoming foundational texts for later councils and Church tradition. The orations reveal how Gregory sought to preserve unity in the Church while navigating imperial pressures and personal struggles, establishing himself as both theologian and rhetorician.

Name: Poems
Metaphysical Tags: Apophasis, Phenomena (Phenomenology), Genesis (Process Realism), Monism, Inversion (Subversive Ontology)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Human Sciences: Education, Human Sciences: Psychology, Liberal Arts: Theology, Liberal Arts: Literature, Liberal Arts: Art/Aesthetics, Liberal Arts: History, Liberal Arts: Philosophy
Short Description: One of the richest Christian poetic corpora of Late Antiquity, blending theology with classical Greek literary form. Written in refined hexameters and elegiacs, they cover themes from the Trinity and Christology to personal struggles, friendship, illness, and the burdens of ecclesiastical office. Some poems serve as doctrinal defenses of Nicene orthodoxy, others as introspective meditations on sin, mortality, and divine grace. Their political intent was to reinforce the authority of Christian doctrine while preserving classical culture within a new symbolic system. Together, they stand as a poetic exploration of Christian theology, bridging Hellenic literary tradition with the emerging Christian worldview of the late Roman Empire.
